xxl.io
Class InputIterator

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.cursors.AbstractCursor
        |
        +--xxl.io.InputIterator
Direct Known Subclasses:
FileInputIterator, URLInputIterator
public class InputIterator
extends AbstractCursor

This class provides an iterator that depends on a data input stream. It iterates over the objects that are read out of the underlying input stream. A converter is used in order to read out the serialized objects.

Additional to the computeNext method this class implements the close and hasNext methods in order to close the underlying input stream when needed.

Example usage (1). 

     // create a new data output stream

     ByteArrayOutputStream baos = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
     DataOutputStream dos = new DataOutputStream(baos);

     // create a new integer converter

     IntegerConverter converter = IntegerConverter.DEFAULT_INSTANCE;

     // write the integers from 0 to 10 to the data output stream

     for (int i = 0; i < 11; i++)
         try {
             converter.writeInt(dos, i);
         }
         catch (IOException ioe) {
             System.out.println("An I/O error occured.");
         }

     // create a new data output stream

     ByteArrayInputStream bais = new ByteArrayInputStream(baos.toByteArray());
     DataInputStream dis = new DataInputStream(bais);

     // create a new input iterator that depends on this data output stream

     InputIterator iterator = new InputIterator(dis, converter);

     // print all elements of the input iterator

     while (iterator.hasNext())
         System.out.println(iterator.next());

     // close the data output stream and the input iterator after use

     try {
         dos.close();
     }
     catch (IOException ioe) {
         System.out.println("An I/O error occured.");
     }
     iterator.close();
Example usage (2). 
     // create a new data output stream

     baos = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
     dos = new DataOutputStream(baos);

     // create a new integer converter

     converter = IntegerConverter.DEFAULT_INSTANCE;

     // write the integers from 0 to 10 to the data output stream

     for (int i = 0; i < 11; i++)
         try {
             converter.writeInt(dos, i);
         }
         catch (IOException ioe) {
             System.out.println("An I/O error occured.");
         }

     // create a new data output stream

     bais = new ByteArrayInputStream(baos.toByteArray());
     dis = new DataInputStream(bais);

     // create a new input iterator that depends on this data output stream

     iterator = new InputIterator(dis, converter);

     // print the elements of the iterator and clear it when 5 has been printed

     while (iterator.hasNext()) {
         int i = ((Integer)iterator.next()).intValue();
         System.out.println(i);
         if (i == 5)
             iterator.close();
     }

     // close the data output stream and the input iterator after use

     try {
         dos.close();
     }
     catch (IOException ioe) {
         System.out.println("An I/O error occured.");
     }
     iterator.close();

See Also:
AbstractCursor, DataInputStream, EOFException, Function, IOException, WrappingRuntimeException

Constructor Detail

InputIterator

public InputIterator(DataInputStream input,
                     Converter converter)
Constructs a new InputIterator that depends on the specified data input stream and uses the specified converter in order to read out the serialized objects.
Parameters:
input - the data input stream that contains the serialized objects of this iteration.
converter - the converter that is used for reading out the serialized objects of this iteration.

InputIterator

public InputIterator(Function newObject,
                     DataInputStream input)
Constructs a new InputIterator that depends on the specified data input stream and uses the specified factory method for initializing an object of this iteration before the input stream is read out. When using this constructor the objects of the iteration must implement the Convertable interface.
Parameters:
newObject - a factory method that is used for initializing an object of this iteration before the input stream is read out.
input - the data input stream that contains the serialized objects of this iteration.
Method Detail

close

public void close()
Closes this iterator and releases any system resources associated with it. This operation is idempotent, i.e., multiple calls of this method takes the same effect as a single call.
This implementation closes the underlying input stream and turns the flag closed to true.
Overrides:
close in class AbstractCursor

computeNext

public void computeNext()
Computes the next element of the iteration.
This implementation tries to read out the next object by calling the read method of the converter on the underlying input stream. When this call throws an EOFException the underlying input stream is exhausted and this iterator will be closed automatically.
Overrides:
computeNext in class AbstractCursor

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
This implementation
Overrides:
hasNext in class AbstractCursor
Returns:
true if the queue has more elements.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples how to use an InputIterator. It can also be used to test the functionality of an InputIterator.
Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
